awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:  An Ethnographic Study of National Security Policies at the Local Level
awd_abstract_narration:
One responsibility of any government is to provide for domestic security. A significant challenge in doing so effectively is that new policies and supporting technologies often turn out to have differential effects at different social structural levels particularly in very heterogenous populations. Some of these effects are unintended and may produce unanticipated local responses. The research supported by this award will use a case study approach and the intensive methodologies of anthropology to examine closely how and why this happens.  The research will help illuminate the inner complex structures of contemporary society, which will contribute to improved social scientific understanding. Findings from the research also will help policy makers bridge the gap between the goals of security reforms and local-level consequences and experiences.

The research will be carried out by University of Massachusetts anthropology doctoral student, Ana Del Conde, under the supervision of Dr. Jacqueline Urla. The researcher will undertake 12  months of research in Mexico where the Merida Initiative, a security reform implemented in 2006 to combat organized crime and drug trafficking, provides an appropriate research opportunity because it has been in place long enough to trace out its local effects. In order to produce a richer and more complete in-depth understanding, the researcher has narrowed her focus to a particular sub-population, indigenous women in the state of Michoacan. Using a mixed-methods approach, she will collect data on how the Initiative is being locally experienced, and how it interacts with other strategies that people have developed locally to protect themselves. The research has a cross-sectional design. Data will be collected in three communities through informal and semi-structured interviews, participant observation, free-listing workshops, and photovoice workshops to produce qualitative and quantitative data, field notes, interview transcripts, and visual narratives. Research results will be shared with multiple stakeholders including research participants, local government officials, and community members who seek to improve the effectiveness of security reforms. Results also will contribute to the growing body of social scientific theoretical work on conflict and security.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
What does it mean to be safe? Can security policies bring protection to all citizens equally? Based in Michoacán, Mexico, the researcher conducted 18 months of ethnographic work, examining how P’urhépecha women in the region experience the neglect of security policies and the manner in which they overcome these vulnerabilities by enacting local alliances of support and protection. Joining women across the P’urhépecha region in their daily activities, and working directly with local indigenous governments and local and regional Civil Society Organizations (CSO’s), this research examined what it means for indigenous women to be secure, their capacity to access the law and justice system, and the disarticulation between these experiences and the state’s discourses of security. By means of this research, the project situates the (in)security concerns of indigenous women in Michoacán within lager discussions of women’s rights, the gendering of securitization, justice and law.

Throughout these 18 months of ethnographic work, the researcher carried out semi-structured and in-depth interviews with indigenous women, government officials and representatives of CSO’s. The researcher also conducted participant observation in daily activities, local events and celebrations, in government events and in court rulings. Finally, the researcher organized three workshops with indigenous women across the region focusing specifically on what it means to be an P’urhépecha women, the rights of indigenous women and the violence they experience in their everyday lives. All of this work was helpful to: 1) explore what resources exist at the local level for women to be able to access the justice system and live a life free of violence; 2) understand the strategies that women are developing at the local level to confront the violence they experience in their everyday lives; 3) learn what are the main security concerns that women have and to identify the specific needs and priorities that they have when it comes to being safe; 4) develop the necessary strategies so that women across the region can access the justice system in an effective way.

This research helped identify the policies, discourses and actions implemented by the Mexican state to guarantee the implementation of women’s rights against violence, and determine how these measures are linked to the mechanisms through which the state tries to combat insecurity. Through the work with local indigenous governments, the researcher analyzed the emergence of these communal processes of governance in the P’urhépecha plateau and explored how they are combating insecurity at the local level. In particular, the researcher paid attention at the different political and social capacities that women are achieving through these governments in order to act against violence and obtain justice. By paying attention to the forms of everyday violence and insecurity that indigenous women in this region encounter, this research illustrates how people experience security concerns differently. It shows how many of the vulnerabilities that women confront are a result of historic structural and institutional violence, which have been further reinforced by the securitization processes in the region. Finally, the research draws attention to the processes through which women are resisting and developing strategies to confront violence while creating new understandings of security and justice.­

The results of the study show how women in the region experience multiple and intersecting form of insecurity that go unrecognized in the securitization processes implemented across Mexico in the past twelve years. In particular, the results of this study show how most of the women that participated in the study have been victims of “private” forms of violence (such as beatings, economic punishments, making them objects of social ridicule, etc.). Furthermore, it shows how the efforts developed at the state level through social policies have had no direct impact on the everyday forms of violence that indigenous women experience. In fact, at many times it has just reinforced their vulnerability through social marginalization and lack of access to the necessary authorities. At the same time, the research findings also bring to the light the processes of social organization that indigenous women are undergoing as a way of addressing these forms of violence and creating the necessary strategies to confront it and change these violent dynamics. All of these findings obtained through this research are likely to make an important contribution to anthropological studies of security, violence and legal anthropology. Particularly, it will help expand the research and literature on feminist anthropology on topics of collective action and human rights.
